subsection.title: Compounding Once a Year
subsection.p: If the interest on a savings account is compounded annually, the amount of money in the account grows exponentially.

sidebyside.p: At the end of each year, we multiply the old balance by another factor of 1.05 to get the new amount. We organize our results into , where A(t) represents the amount of money in the account after t years. For this example, a formula for the amount after t years is A(t) = 100(1.05)^t.

subsection.p: In general, for an initial investment of P dollars at an interest rate r compounded annually, we have the following formula for the amount accumulated after t years.

assemblage.title: Annual Interest

subsection.p: This function describes exponential growth with an initial value of P and a growth factor of b = 1 + r. The interest rate r, which indicates the percent increasepercent increase in the account each year, corresponds to a growth factorgrowth factor of 1 + r. The notion of percent increase is often used to describe the growth factor for quantities that grow exponentially.

subsection.title: Compounding n-Times a Year
subsection.p:
If we have a principal of P and an interest rate r, then by compounding this interest rate n-times a year we mean the following:
Rather than apply the interest rate r one time over the course of a year, we instead apply an interest of \dfrac{r}{n} a total of n times over the course of the year.

assemblage.title: Compound Interest

warning.p:
The growth factor of
A(t) = P\left(1 + \dfrac{r}{n}\right)^{nt}
is not 1+\dfrac{r}{n}. Recall that when a function is written in the form P(b)^t the growth factor is b. So, we need to rewrite our function in this form. We do this as follows:
A(t)=P\left(1 + \dfrac{r}{n}\right)^{nt} = P\left[\left(1+\dfrac{r}{n}\right)^n\right]^t.
If we set
b=\left(1+\dfrac{r}{n}\right)^n,
then we have rewritten A(t) in the form P(b)^t, and thus the growth factor is \left(1+\dfrac{r}{n}\right)^n.

subsection.p:
If you have a sharp eye, then you've realized that the Annual Interest formula can come from the Compound Inteterest formula! Since annual means once a year, we let n=1 in the Compound Interest formula to get:
A(t) = P\left(1 + \dfrac{r}{1}\right)^{1t} = P\left(1 + r\right)^{t}.
So, the nominal interest rate is the same as the annual interest rate if your n is equal to 1. In general, these are NOT the same. You will be asked to translate between nominal and annual. The NOTE after shows how to go from nominal to annual.

statement.p:
During a period of rapid inflation, prices of a pound of butter rose by 24 compounded twice a year. At the beginning of the inflationary period, a pound of butter cost 2.
Write a function that gives the price of a pound of butter t years after inflation began.
How much did a pound of butter cost after 3 years? After 15 months?

li.p: Looking at our compound interest formula A(t) = P\left(1 + \dfrac{r}{n}\right)^{nt}, we know that we are compounding twice a year, so n=2, and the nominal rate is 24, so r=.24. The problem also tells us the original price of a pound of butter was 2, so P=2. Using this information, we get the formula A(t) = 2\left(1 + \dfrac{.24}{2}\right)^{2t}= 2(1.12)^{2t}.
